content.description:
This shares the start with "

Moose Whisperer

". Climb that route until the crack splits. Take the left crack, and work around an awkward bulge, finishing at the shared anchor chains. There is an extension to this route that steps around left and up a slightly overhanging crack to anchors on the top (another 15 feet, 5.10ish).
content.protection:
Gear to 3", nuts and hexes work well in the thinner section up high, and chains. This shares an anchor with

Piggly Wiggly

or you can climb to the top chains, another 15 feet at a slightly harder grade.
content.location:
Follow a faint trail skirting the base of the east face (this is the face you see as you approach the dome) until you see the obvious Y crack under a large roof. Climb the same start as "

Moose Whisperer

". It is 15 feet right of "

Piggly Wiggly

."

content.description: The crux is figuring out the first 2 bolts and clipping the third. Then it's a cruise to the top.
content.location: On the East side, walk along the climber's trail a couple hundred feet until you reach the low angle slab with three routes on it. This is the middle bolted route.

content.description:
This is more fun nubbin wrestling with some stemming thrown in. It has some of the largest quartz nubbins on the entire dome. It shares the last bolt and anchors with "

Ladder Made of Thorns

."
content.protection:
5 bolts to chains, this shares the last bolt and anchors with "

Ladder Made Of Thorns

".
content.location: Climb the right side of a rectangular slab on the west face. Start in a deep, wide cleft. Scramble, chimney, and stem your way to the first bolt.

climbs.name: The Sound of One Hand Stemming

content.description:
The beta is in the name... it climbs the funky, black water tube about 20 feet right of "

Black Rose Stem

".
content.location:
Start on the same wide, sloping ledge as "

Black Rose Stem

" just 20 feet to the right. Walk along the climber's trail at the base of the east side until you can access the wide ledge under the route. There is a fun toprope problem directly under the anchor.... It needs a few bolts, a grade, and a name....

content.description: Start with difficult moves following the steep crack up and left out to the obvious short handcrack. From here, continue out the flake hanging above. Once you are over the flake, move up the corner and water groove until you can escape left to the chains.
content.protection: A single rack to red Camalot and a set of nuts. An RP(maybe #2) can be nice mid-crux. A blue Camalot protects the easy upper corner. There are chains up top.

content.description: SBF is a short but fun, little toprope. Climb a steep section with a bit of a bulge to a slabby water groove/corner. This is worth climbing, but it is not worth putting bolts on it.
content.protection: Two bolts on top with no chains. Walk off to the north.
content.location:
Start right and around a corner from "

Righty Too Tighty

". Scramble right then up and left to gain the ridgeline on top of the dome (easy fifth class). There are two bolts on the left side of the ridge right above this route. If you see the chains for "

RTT

," you've gone too far.

content.description: This has three little sections of steepening slab. Climb a puzzling, low angle slab to a blocky section, finishing with a steep, funky water tube. There are lots of hidden holds on this one.
content.location: It is the rightmost bolted route on the low angle slab, 150 feet down the east side climber's trail.

content.description: Climb a lower angle water weakness, clipping bolts out right. This is a good first lead.
content.location: It is the 1st route you come to when walking around to the west face of the dome. Scramble up a low angle ramp to the base of the prominent water path on the far left side of the formation.

content.description: Getting on this route might be the crux for some people. Stem and thrash your way up a flaring chimney until it is possible to step onto the slab finish. This can be climbed staying right of the bolts for a much harder climb (5.10).
content.location:
This route starts on the far left side of the east face (the side you see as you approach the dome). Look for bolts on the right side of a slightly hidden chimney. A trail is starting to develop along the east side of the dome that will take you right to the start. It shares anchors with "

Whisper to the Baby Moose

".

content.description: Climb a huge, concave-faced block. The crux is getting off the ground, through a roof and onto the concave face.
content.location:
It is on the far right side of the west face, 100 feet right of "

Climbin' Trees

".

content.description: There is a lot going on with this one! Start with a bit of slab through a cool intrusion, over a bulge to more slab. Then work through/around an awkward roof to more bulging overlaps.
content.location: This route is on the taller, center section of the west face. Look for an intruding dike feature that snakes its way up and right. "Raining Rose Pebbles" crosses the lower left side of this dike.

content.description: Climb up bulges past the raspberry bushes into the huge corner. Go through the roof crack out right starting with your hands into a few deep flared fist jams.  Continue up then left to the crack through the headwall (save a hand-sized piece for the end).
content.protection: Singles to #3 or #4 Camalot with an extra #2 or #3. There are chains at the top.
content.location: This is the obvious flake/corner system on the left end of the east side. It is very visible on the hike in.

content.description: Moose has a hard start to a rest. Then wander through a couple of overlaps and a final bulge to the top.
content.location: On the East side of the dome, walk the east side climber's trail a couple hundred feet. There are three bolted routes on the first slab you come to. Moose is the left route with a steeper start.

content.description: Climb straight up the center of large slab using various size, sharp crystal holds. This shares the last bolt and anchors with the next route to the right.
content.location: This is found on the large slab, left center of the west face.

content.description: This is the best route on the dome (so far). Climb a vertical section of a dike featur with crimpy nubbin fun above and below. Pulling on the dike feature offers something different than the typical nubbin crimping here.
content.location:
It is 15 feet right of "

Raining Rose Pebbles

". Look for the vertical section of the obvious dike feature. Keep the bolts to your left as you climb up the dike.

content.description:
This was originally put up to access a couple of toprope routes. It starts on "

Black Rose Stem

" and climbs the first three bolts of that route. Look up and right for the fourth bolt and anchors, the same anchors as "

The Sound of One Hand Stemming

".
content.location:
Climb the first three bolts of "

Black Rose Stem

", which starts in a wide, black, water groove. Walk along the faint climber trail at the base of the east side of the dome until you can scramble up to a wide sloping ledge under the black, water streak.

content.description: This is a fun romp with four different sections: low angle slab with 2 bolts to a good rest; thin slab moves past the next 2 bolts to a rest; vertical layback moves past 2 more bolts to another good rest; and climb past the final 2 bolts on more vertical terrain to the anchors.
content.location:
It is 15 feet right of "

Nubbing Up Roses

". Find a slab that is sandwiched between two monster blocks on the far right side of the west face.

content.description: Do a fun stemming start up a black water groove. Move left at the top of the tube to surmount a little headwall. Then climb a slabby finish.
content.location: Look for an obvious, black water groove on the center of the east face when approaching the dome. Walk up to the base of the climb from the right side and belay from a large slabby bench directly below the black water tube. As of 12-1 -2012, this is the only route on the east face of the dome.

content.description: Start with a small, diagonal crack through a bulge. As the crack ends, you will work up and right through several overlaps. Gear options can be found under each overlap. This route is considerably easier when using the dead tree leaned up against the start.
content.protection: Small to medium cams and nuts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is 20 feet right of "

Climbin' Trees

."
